course.subject: COMP
course.name: Operating Systems
course.description: Principles, purpose and structure of operating systems; processes, threads, and multi-threaded programming; CPU scheduling; synchronization, mutual exclusion; memory management and virtual memory; device management; file systems, security and protection.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2611 OR [(ELEC 2300 OR ELEC 2350) AND (COMP 2011 OR COMP 2012H)]

reviews.author: The_Unknown
reviews.title: Exam is no longer a memorization game but garbage gradings remain
reviews.comment_content:
After revamp, the content became more practical than previous terms where memorization = good marks.
Now (or at least for this semester), the exams were open book and most questions were concept related questions.

From introduction slide, the course outline:

Overview (3 lectures)
Basic OS concept (2 lectures)
System architecture (1 lectures)
Process and Thread (13 lectures)
Process and thread (4 lectures)
CPU scheduling (4 lectures)
Synchronization (2 lectures)
Deadlock (2 lectures)
Memory and storage (8 lectures)
Memory management (2 lectures)
Virtual memory (3 lectures)
Secondary storage (1 lectures)
File systems and implementation (2 lectures)
Security and protection (2 lectures)
Security (1 lecture)
Protection (1 lecture)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Nothing much to say. Didn't really understand much in the lectures. Needed to revise before and after lecture.

To be fair, the instructor was helpful when we asked the questions. But it was hard following the lecture at times. So, the questions were kinda limited.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty bad gradings. The mean is probably C+ or something.

Mid Term: Mean - 73 / My Score 85 (Total 20%)
HWs: Mean - 88ish / My Score 93ish (Total 20%)
Project: Mean- mid 90ish?? / My Score 100 (Total 30%)
Finals: Mean 69 / My Score 72 (Total 30%)

Final Grade - B :(

The grades are a disaster. I mean, if you just take the mean of everything you have 81.4%. So, the average score ought to be between 79-83%. My score is 87.2 but grade is B. That usually happens when mean is c+. Not a good grading for a compulsory course.

My advise for exams is to take care of semantics/ calculation errors coz it is pretty easy to have them. For instance, I lost 6 marks because I forgot to add distance from head to first pending in disk scheduling seek time (I knew we needed to add head distance but I was in hurry and table starts from next pending job so I missed it. It was a very very regretful mistake) and 3 more marks because of calculation mistake.
Now, I will spend the holidays thinking that if I had double-checked, maybe I would have gotten b+ or more. :( Don't be like me.

Better take the course in spring. From other reviews, I can see that the grading is much lenient. Moreover, if past papers are any indication, it is easier too.
reviews.comment_workload: There isn't much workload tbh. Pretty light. Although you may need to spend a lot of time understanding stuff.

reviews.author: È´òÊµ∑ÂçÉÊ≠å
reviews.title: Never trust people who give a "A" on GRADING or say it is good grade, those are illusions
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Introduction and basics of OS
Chapter 2: System architecture
Chapter 3: Process
Chapter 4: Thread
Chapter 5: CPU scheduling
Chapter 6-7: Synchronization
Chapter 8: Deadlock
Chapter 9: Memory management
Chapter 10: Virtual memory
Chapter 11: Secondary storage
Chapter 13-14: File systems and implementation
Chapter 17: Protection

Most are factual things so you just need to comprehend and memorize. There are some programming part but not that much so the content is not that fun.

In this semester, prof make a historical decision -- making the exam open-book. Therefore, you don't need to cram everything into your brain anymore. However, exam will more focus on conceptual things rather than factual or superficial things so you still need to comprehend the content.

Make sure you know and master every algorithm (CPU scheduling, Banker's, etc.) in this course. Since the exam more focuses on concept now technical things such as algorithm will very likely be examined
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Li's teaching is good, especially when teaching different algorithm. He tried to run the scenario step-by-step and explain how each step is formed so that you are easier to know how the algorithm is working.  

Also, he explains concepts clearly. Sometimes the lecture notes explains vaguely or even only put some images or figure and explain nothing (like another post suggests, the lecture notes are very likely just copied from textbook= =). Fortunately, Prof. Li will try to explain the scenario and let us know what is going on. He is willing to answer questions as well

For TA, I only attend those being held by Peter. Peter teaches well. Concepts are explained clearly. Also, Peter is in charge of the project assignment so you should at least attend his tutorial for knowing what is going on for the project.

Fun fact, it looks like Peter is a big fan of Squid Game as his powerpoint shows a lot of Squid Game scene. He even used the tug war scene to explain the concept of deadlock
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Homework (20%)
2. Project assignment (30%)
3. Midterm (20%)
4. Final exam (30%)

Assignment costs 50% so don't be lazy and think exams can carry you.

Never trust people who give A to this part or said it is good grade. It is just an illusion of survivorship bias.

People who give A to GRADING and said good grade is just because they get an A range in the course. If you look at their score, mostly are overall score 95% or above and get A+. That is equivalent to "Your mother is female", which is useless and nonsense

The truth is that the grading is ultimately crazy. Once your score falls below 90%, your grade drops very quickly, The interval of a subgrade is only like 1% to 2% (Reference from Goop, 89% B+, 87% B, 85% B-, 83% C+). Moreover, mean score is C+, a clear evidence of broken grading

When you feel satisfied for making an overall score 80% and gets above the mean score, sorry you still get a C+ only. Grading is a complete disaster. The return is likely not proportional to effort so don't put that much effort on this course

I got overall 85% and only got B-. I thought I finally make a good shot in COMP course but eventually the shxt grading just make me losing hope on any COMP courses.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is medium

1. Homework
4 homework, not very hard. Usually there are both computation / algorithm question and essay question. The latter one is troublesome because you don't know what they want. However, essay questions appears less frequently in exams.

Moreover, many questions are just copied from internet and you can copy them as well for securing your marks (After reading GRADING part you should know these marks are important for your grade)

2. Project assignment
aka, programming assignment. You will use C (not C++) so try to get familiar with the syntax. All test cases will be given beforehand so you can debug more easily as there won't be crazy hidden cases to screw you up like COMP2011 and COMP2012

There are two PA. Usually the first one will be something related to API and system call, which is very different from PA in COMP2011 or COMP2012 so it will be harder.

But the second one, for this semester it is Banker's algorithm. Once you know how the algorithm works and the coding part is just same level as COMP2011 (some array manipulation)...  

3. Midterm & Final exam
Since it is open-book, print every lecture notes out. Also, there are chapter summary (which I suspected that it is copied from textbook) available but they are not that useful, because the WHOLE PAGE ARE WORDS. You won't want to reference it during exam. Try to make more concise summary by yourself. Although this will cost you some time, when you finish making your own "cheat sheet", you should have finished going through all lecture notes. It will be more efficient than just simply reading.

Key thing for exam is : CAREFULNESS. After reading GRADING part you should know -- Careless mistakes can kill you very easily.

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: An improving course, but still rooms for improvement
reviews.comment_content:
Lots of boring theory and conceptual stuff from OS. Not much hands-on experience.

Topics include:
- Operating System Structures
- Process/thread Scheduling and Synchronization
- Deadlocks
- Virtual-Memory Management
- Mass-Storage Systems
- File-System Interface & Implementation

They put a lot of details in the slides, which I don't really like. This course somehow becomes remembering the little details but not understanding the main concept.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He sometimes teaches OK. He sometimes teaches very badly. It quite depends on the topic.

I think he did explain the concepts of some code clearly. For example, when he talks about monitor or deadlock, he go through them slowly and walk you through the code. For other times, he just use the whiteboard pen knocking the screen and drawing weird circles on the whiteboard. Quite boring and difficult to follow.

Lecture video of another lecture class is provided this semester. So you can use that for revision. (Don't skip too many class tho. You know what happened if you follow the UST secret recently....)
reviews.comment_grading:
The instructors said they have started revamping this course this semester. The format for the midterm and final have clearly changed. More practical questions were added (some of them you won't see in past papers) and the Q&A reciting questions become a little bit harder. Both midterm and final have the same mean score of 64.1, which is much lower than previous offerings.

My stats:
HW1: 98/100 (Mean: 88.9)
HW2: 100/100 (Mean: 83.5)
HW3: 99/100 (Mean: 86.2)
HW4: 100/100 (Mean: 86.8)
HW Total: 397/400 => 19.85/20
Project 1: 143/143 (Mean: 125.1) => 10/10
Project 2: 80/100 (Mean: 71.6) => 12/15
Midterm: 85/100 (Mean: 64.1, SD: 16, Max: 95) => 17/20
Final: 86/100 (Mean: 64.1, SD: Not released, Max: 97) => 30.1/35
Overall: 88.95/100 => A

+1.3 sd in midterm and similar results in final. I believe getting an A is quite fair. The grading scheme is much better than previous offerings, and you don't need 96% overall to get an A. The course has definitely improved. Maybe there was too much negative feedback last semester.
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to spend some time after the lecture to understand the content. Usually you still don't know what the fun that thing is after the lecture. Asking the TAs or reading the textbook maybe a good idea.

For the HW, go google the questions. Do Ctrl-F in the course textbook. You may still get the answers wrong even you understand the concepts. Try to change/extract some keywords when googling. They have modified the wordings of some questions a little bit to prevent you google.

The coding part of the projects are easy. However, for the report part, you don't know how detail you should write. I got low marks in Project 2 report because of that. So, go seek for some sources and ask the TAs for some opinion.

reviews.comment_content:
I don't know what I have learned üò´. This course is like a huge collection of "fun" facts about OS but I don't know why I need to learn them.

Around 75% of the content are boring theories, jargon, and small "fun" facts about operating systems. Most of the concepts you learn won't appear in the following chapters. The remaining 25% are programming in C and calling APIs from the POSIX (UNIX) library. The programming part is kind of interesting though.  

[The course syllabus is the same as previous semesters. Not gonna repeat here]

Every slide is stuffed with many words and jargon that you need to remember. The slides are also poorly organized as they didn't put any dividers to indicate a change in topic within the chapter.

This course is a large shit that every CS student needs to swallow. Just hold your breath and swallow quick, and you should be fine üòâ

üìÉ Professor
I'm rating him an "E" grade because he is like a human text-to-speech machine. He reads off words from the lecture slides line by line in monotone without much explanation. I highly recommend you to attend LI Bo's class since he is much better in explaining concepts.

üìÉ TA
Other TAs are also human text-to-speech machines, except for TA Peter CHUNG. Peter actually gives shit about his job (which is rare in UST) and he is passionate in answering students' questions and sharing some exam skills. He is probably the best TA you'll ever meet üëç

üîπ Project (PA x 2) - 30% (Each for 15%)
üîπ Mid-term - 20%
üîπ Final - 30%
(MT and Final are closed book and NOT cumulative)

üìàStatistics:

PA1 mean not released
PA2 - Mean: 97.8 ; SD: 11.3

Final - Mean: 71.5 ; SD: 14

I got 97.7/100 in HW, full marks in project, +0.87SD in mid-term and +0.79SD in final. My final grade is A.

I think they improved the grading so it's not likely that you will get C range for being +0.5SD as seen in an old review üòÇ
reviews.comment_workload:
TLDR: Average workload, each HW could take you 3~5 hours, PA1 is difficult by PA2 can be completed within half an hour.

üìÉ HW
Each homework has around 15 MC questions and some LQ. Some questions can be answered by copying and pasting lecture note content, while some are more conceptual. Each HW should take you 3~5 hours so it's not too bad.

üìÉ Project (PA)
PA1 is quite complicated as it involves POSIX APIs like fork(), but you can complete it within 3 hours. PA2 involves implementing a simple algorithm (Banker's algorithm). It's even easier than the PAs in COMP2111 and this should take you 30 minutes.

üìÉ Studying
You need extra time revising the lecture notes since it is basically a clusterfuck of concepts, jargons and "fun" facts. You may want to spend extra time on fork() and semaphores since the exam questions can get hard.

reviews.author: B.C.
reviews.title: Great course after revamp
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
Process and Thread
Memory and Management
Security and Protection (new topic this semester, spanned just 2 lectures though)

C and UNIX platform programming were chosen as the tools for the projects this semester, which in my opinion is much better than using those educational OSes like in previous offerings.
Project 1: pipes for processes (in command line)
Project 2: malloc/free simplified
I think these are more useful as a starter to OS programming and design.

Despite a compulsory course that might appear boring at first sight, 3511 is pretty important in letting us understand how computer systems work and demystifying what we took for granted for high-level programming. Clearing up these concepts are essential in learning about OS design, systems programming, security, networking - and the performance issues in system design. So I think it's a good experience overall.

The reference book Three Easy Pieces seems to be a nice resource to learn more if you had the time.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Li is a great presenter, and was patient to explain concepts from motivation to details.

The course teaching staff were responsible, even in the face of the change of lecture format in this semester in the last month. Lecture videos are sufficient but I do recommend going to Prof Li's lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 20%
Final 30%
Homeworks x3 20%
Projects x2 30%

For me:
Midterm: 70.5% (around mean)
Final: 91.5% (around mean)
Homework 1: 92%, 2: 95%, 3: 83% (below mean)
Project 1: 100%, 2: 100%
Ended up with B+

Careless mistakes in longer questions in homeworks and exams can cost you a sub-grade (things like CPU scheduling and synchronization problems), so be careful when you write the answers.
reviews.comment_workload:
Projects were each given a month to complete, and homeworks each around 3 weeks, so time is sufficient.
The work is not that difficult but requires understanding, so it's pretty manageable. As Prof Li said, the homeworks are just for helping us to revise.

reviews.author: B.T.
reviews.title: Shit Professor. A highly competitive course. Hardwork pays off (by doing past papers).
reviews.comment_content:
Standard Operating Systems. I guess the syllabus has not changed for 20 years, so looking at any of the other reviews shall be fine.

The first half of the course up to deadlock are more organized, and is better illustrated with examples. I will give a B to this half

The second half about file management and memory are much more vague and not really well presented by the instructors nor being self-explanatory in the notes. I give a D here.

Btw, previous semesters have included security, but it seems this semester has cut it again. Not sure how the department would like to organize the lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very bad. Probably one of the worst five professors I have met in HKUST.

Firstly, the professor speaks with incomprehensible chinese accent. I can not really understand her lectures.

Also, this professor is arrogant af. I will describe she being passive aggresive. Those students who do not "get" it may think she is nice explaining and encouraging asking questions. However, whenever someone asks a question, she responds in a way that "you should have learnt this", "you should have learnt that", with a mocking smile which is not a smile at all.

Thirdly, she always say "we expect students to learn xxx", "after this lecture, students are expected to have learnt xxx". Yes, these are the exact wordings from her, which I personally think super weird. Com'on! I know you are some big person in the department of CSE, I know you may have invloved in designing this course or whatever, I am here to learn Operating Systems, not to learn what you expect students to learn.

While this prof is worse af, however, OS courses in UST seemingly have no prof good, Li Bo or Wang Wei are just also a "pass" professer imo. Anyway, you can still reg her since attendace is not taken and you can always watch lecture videos from other profs which I beleive most of us did.

If you can take it in exchange, please do so.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW: 4 x 5%
Project (i.e. coding): 3 x 10%
Midterm: 20%
Final: 30%

Me:
HW1 83% (mean 91.8)
HW2 100% (mean 86.98)
HW3 93% (mean 93.48)
HW4 98% (mean 94.41)

Project all 100% (mean 94.0, 94.7, 95.47)

Midterm 92% (mean 73.48)
Final 79% (mean 70.3)

Overall score: 90.8 (overall mean: 81-82)
Letter grade: A-

As mentioned in other posts, A-range is fine. However, please note that some homeworks, PA1 and final exam are all not easy tasks, yet the averages are quite high. Please expect to pay efforts in working on HWs and PAs, including sending emails back and forth to ask for clarification, as well as to do dozens of past paper if you want to secure an A-range, because all the rest of the top students are doing the same. Fxxking competitive.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 homeworks, 3 projects, 1 midterm and final.
Homeworks are not difficult, but must need careful. Attend all make-up tutorials for hw and ask TA to clarify if needed. Losing few points in hw may lose you a sub-grade.

Projects are fine. Actually they are just Programming Assignments using C language. The first project is very tough, as I believe no one knows forks or pipes before taking this course. However, PA2 and 3 are like some labs in comp2011, if you know pointers and structs, then you are super fine.

Midterm and Final: midterm easy but final is not. Also, time is not enough for the final exam. Please go through all past papers of the previous 10 years before taking the exam (source can be easily found). You don't need other revision beyond that.

reviews.author: rind
reviews.title: They should name this course as "Introduction to Operating Systems"
reviews.comment_content:
The material is the same with previous semesters.
One thing I don't like about this course is everything is too abstract. Not much real code examples, not much detail about Linux (Well, this course is operating systemS).

Of course, from the start of the lecture, Li Bo said the course content has to take care of people who are completely new to OS . I would say the content is moderate for a compulsory course. Hope that they will open more advanced OS electives.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Li Bo's teaching is very good. However, to enjoy his teaching, you have to understand his mainland accent (not heavy). Sometimes, he speak very fast and make the sentence confusing, but he is very open to questions and even send emails to everyone clarifying some common questions he received from students.

TAs are also responsible. Especially Peter, I admire his effort in explaining the projects in lab session and give a comprehensive documentation.
reviews.comment_grading:
Well, no longer competitive for the A-range.
In previous offerings, 90% should give A-, and 95% will give A+.
This year, since the page table question is very hard, the mean drops compared to previous years.

Midterm: mean: 67.37, sd: 18.45
Final: mean: 68.95, sd: 16.71

For me, 94.5% gets an A+, and I know someone 90.x% gets an A. The competition in the A-range is less competitive. However, it seems like the mean grade is still C+, so still a bad grade course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Open book for every exam! No memorizing anymore!
The tutorial sessions usually cover lecture reviews, project briefing. Note that sometimes Li Bo will put examples in the lab sessions, do remember to read the pdf for each lab session so that you won't miss these extra examples.

There are no hidden test case for projects (PAs), the 30% will be easy to get.

Hw is somehow confusing, especially for Hw3 (Designed by Xuhao) is the homework with lowest mean (75% only), make sure you email the TAs if you don't understand what the question is really asking.

The exams are similar to previous semesters, except the page table part in the final exam. You have to be a human MMU to translate all the 32-bit binary logical address into physical address and search the content in a large memory table. It is very easy to have mistakes even if you understand how to do it (13 marks in total for that part). I would say the difficulty of the exam starts increasing.

He will also send us many emails to further explain the concepts taught in class, which is good for those who want to learn more about it.

The accent of professor is little bit difficult to understand. But it is still acceptable.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework x4 20%
Project  x2 30%
Midterm 20%
Final 30%

All examination is close-book and non-cumulative.

Midterm mean is around 81.2, sd 16.7
Final mean is 70.6, sd 16.88

Overall: 94.275 / 100
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
It is all about memorization.

For homework, you can find the answer by just searching the lecture slides so that it is not difficult at all. Some of the questions you may need to google it.

For projects, there are 2 individual "projects" in this semester. Actually it is just a coding homework.
One is about system call, another one is Banker's algorithm. They are not difficult and you can find many useful things in lab powerpoint. It won't cost you much time and you can expect many students can get full mark in 2 projects.

The major workload is come from midterm and final. You just need to recite everything in powerpoint to do the examinations. There are no techniques at all. It is just a memorization competition.

You may find the past paper is useful for you to do preparation. So get some of them to prepare before examination.

reviews.author: Vincent Liu
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course on operating systems. The topics will include the basic concepts of operating systems, process and threads, inter-process communications, process synchronization, scheduling, memory allocation, page and segmentation, secondary storage, file systems, security, and protection. It contains the key concepts as well as examples drawn from a variety of real systems such as Microsoft Windows and Linux.

Mean grading of LI, Bo --> C+

Midterm 20%
Exam 35%

reviews.author: {Curly Braces}
reviews.title: Kernel never dies, but definitely not my heart
reviews.comment_content:
The course syllabus is as follows:
Chapter 1: Introduction and basics of OS
Chapter 2: System architecture
Chapter 3: Process
Chapter 4: Thread
Chapter 5: CPU scheduling
Chapter 6-7: Synchronization
Chapter 8: Deadlock
Chapter 9: Memory management
Chapter 10: Virtual memory
Chapter 11: Secondary storage
Chapter 13-14: File systems and implementation
Chapter 17: Security
Chapter 18: Protection (Omitted this semester)

The concepts are pretty much typical compared to most OS courses outside. Originally it was heavy memorization, but the memorization needed is smaller due to the exam changed to open book this semester.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Judging from no reviews about Charles in this course, I think this is the first time he teaches this course. I must say that despite the course having rather boring contents, Charles still tried his best to make changes to the course.
Firstly, Charles tried not to read everything from the slides and call it a day. He once used programming demonstration to explain the concepts of process, which I think is an advancement, judging from how lecture notes is probably direct copy from textbook (I will put my theory on this later).
Also, he makes coffee questions every lecture in order to make the lecture less boring, and, encourages students to self-study after lecture. He also set up a complain board for us to point out the problem of the course, and try to tackle them down.

For the slides, it is a total disaster. Wordy, and the main points are all well-hidden inside the slides. To add insult to injury, when I search up for references to questions in homework, I found the slides of the OS courses in other universities, and they have exactly the same slide contents. Same examples, same images, and even some with the same theme (with dinosaurs at the corners). This is how I come to the theory that this course's slides are probably direct copy from textbook, judging from the textbook recommended to us also have a dinosaur as cover.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grades is really broken, similar to COMP3111 in this semester. Even so, it is quite expected as this course is famous for bad gradings.

Grading scheme:
Homework 20% (4 Homework, 5% each)
Project 30% (2 PAs, 15% each)
Midterm 20%
Final 20%

My score is as follows:
Homework: 389/400 (Mean: 90 + 88 + 87 + 87/400 = 352/400)
PA: 200/200 (Mean: 91 + 93/200 = 194/200)
Midterm: 79/100 (Mean: ~74/100)
Final: 75/100 (Mean: ~70/100)

Final Grade: B (87.75%)

After looking through goop post about the grade of this course, I think the grade range would be as follows:
> 90% = A-range
85-90% = B-range
< 85% = C-range or below
While the mean is around 82.5%.

"Kernel never dies", that's what Charles always emphasize in pre-midterm lectures. In contrast, my heart simply died after trying my best to understand all the concepts and taken my best shot in exams, yet being played like an idiot in the exams and got a broken grade in the end.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload in this course is actually light. I downshifted the grade to D here because of the depression the exams gave me (This is personal, I know).

Homework is basically quite easy if you ask. As most MCQs and the LQs can simply Google and find the answer. For the calculations and worked questions, just double check and you will be safe.

PAs is also another easy work to handle. Since all test cases for the PAs are released and no hidden cases, just follow the lab slides and it can be done easily. Remember don't hard code as you need to explain how it works. The only challenge is your own sanity against segmentation faults without knowing why.

For the exams, they are open book and non-accumulative. For the lecture materials, only chapter summary is enough. Another thing that is recommended to bring in would be the compilation of LQs from homework and past papers. For midterm, lab materials (Especially process and pipe ones) are also recommended.

The midterm. Sorry let me put this personally. Who the F*CK come up with the idea on expressing a timeline in a TABLE????? Why you have to be WEIRD and not following the past papers and just use a number line to express real-time scheduling?????? Have you ever studied data visualization before??????? (Actually me neither, but I was just being salty so yeah) I lost 8 marks because I can't determine whether the column t = 1 means the instant right before t = 1 or the instant right after t = 1. I know I was being like an idiot in that, but oh well. I pretty much got a mixed feelings after the midterm marks was released. (The question is put at attachment, if you are curious)
OK, now to be serious. Since the exams are open-book this time, the questions this time are more programming based. As I am not familiar with the lab materials, another 8 marks was down the drain. As the exams of this course in future semesters are probably also open-book, so remember to study, and better bring the lab materials for the midterm.

The final is basically similar to midterm, just a race of carefulness. Again, this time it also involves more programming. Since the final exam is non-accumulative and post-midterm labs are just lecture reviews, there are basically nothing special needed from the labs.

reviews.author: toxicboi
reviews.title: Memorisation = A
reviews.comment_content:
I am writing this review in the summer after taking the course and I have already forgotten what it was about lol.

Went through my materials again, internally cringed a little, but got the basic idea.

The content means well, tells you about how operating systems are classified, and how they work, schedule different processes, avoid deadlocks etc.

Its quite interesting if you always wondered how your own computers and smartphones are able to do so many tasks at the same time without breaking down. But as most of the courses in HKUST, they are out dated, and do not reflect on what the current situation is.

Anyway, if you want to graduate with a CS degree, you have to take this course, so theres no point complaining about it, just buckle in.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Never went to class, went to lab once and it was horrible.

The TA was really good if you go to him for help

Lecture notes are good, but a but hard to understand without background knowledge. Use Youtube, and then go to the lectures.

The summaries were a blessing, but surprisingly many people didnt even know they existed.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 homework (written assignments) ‚Äì 20% (5% each)

I simply googles most of the answers, or copy pasted them from the book or lecture slides. Pretty easy. But application based questions are good for exam practice.

2 projects (programming assignments) ‚Äì 25%

These projects were quite easy, if you dont already know how to use the terminal (shame on you), this will give you the basics, rest just follow the instructions. The unfortunate part is that, there is no scope for creativity in these assignments, all students have to have the exact same output.

Midterm Exam - 20%
Final Exam - 35%

The key to scoring well in the exams here is MEMORISATION.

Memorise the lecture slides, and do the application based questions as if you could do them with your eyes closed.

I got close to full on all homeworks, and projects.

Midterm, I got mean +0.5sd and final i really became a zombie and memorised everything, got a very good score (mean + 2sd)

Got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: They tend to keep you busy throughout the semester, but its not much. Doing the homeworks and projects a day before is enough. Study well for the exams.

reviews.author: takecare
reviews.title: Eh...
reviews.comment_content:
All the content is the same as previous semesters. The notes are a bit old and nothing new or interesting inside. It is really poor to have no practical stuff in the course... of low nutritional value.

If you have a chance to exchange out,DO NOT take this here.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good instructors and helpful tutors cannot help the boring course materials which intrinsically suck.
reviews.comment_grading:
Just a matter of memorization, but this cannot reflect what you spend!
From 92% of A grade to 82% of C grade, each sub-grade only differs about less than 2% of the total. Once you have a slip in the midterm or in the final exam, you can just say goodbye to B grade and above.
reviews.comment_workload:
The 2 sets of coding assignments are not practical, yet super easy.
The 4 sets of homework are even easier because they are just copied from Internet sources.

reviews.author: khimizi
reviews.title: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE IF YOU HAVE OTHER CHOICES
reviews.comment_content: Normal contents on the operating system. Exactly the same as the content from the textbook operating system concepts with no additional materials taught. In fact, the lecture slides are made of extractions from the textbook but with countless typos.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The two professors are simply reading out sentences written on the lecture slides with no additional explanation. But one thing is different, Bo Li seems to be more confident while teaching the course than Kai chen.

However, both of the instructors fail to notice flaws in lecture slides when they are reading them out. I doubt whether they understand what they are teaching since all of the typos are identified by the students. And even after the professor realizes the typos after students raise questions,  he won't correct them, leaving the incorrect lecture slides on the website for months until students wrote emails to explicitly ask him to correct the slides.

In fact, I feel that the IA is more capable of teaching the course than the professor.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair enough.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.
3 PA with all of the test cases released. Each PA took from 1 hour ~ 4 hours to finish. They are quite simple.
About 1 HW each month, the questions are simple but they are not clearly written so I sometimes feel that the questions are hard to understand.

reviews.title: Grading Sucks
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly discussed and focus on the software layer and the Operating System:

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of the course is not that high and hard. Only 4 Homeworks and 2 Project Assignments.

Homeworks are very easy to find the answer on the lecture notes, including some Mulitple Choice questions and few Short questions.

reviews.author: manselrian
reviews.comment_content:
Contain some outdated information.  It devoted half a chapter on very simple disk scheduling algorithms when SSDs are massively gaining market share from HDDs in recent years.   The information about CPUs seem outdated too.  

This course doesn't really gives you much insight/understanding about OS, its valuable content is around 1.5 credits.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecture notes were not designed by the lecturer, but they are messy and non-systematic.  Small pieces of information are all over the place, with 1-2 sentences of description.
reviews.comment_grading: Did not check with many to see the overall grading, but the mean grade seems low in general.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload, 4 homeworks with 2 "programming project".  
The homeworks are mostly essay type question, fairly easy.  
Ironically and sadly, there are also essay type questions in the programming assignments too.  And I think most students type more words on those short questions than actual codes.  
The good side is that the course won't be that intensive, but you won't learn much either.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Didn't attend many lecture, but Prof. Li are willing to reply email if we have questions.

TA Peter is quite good, he taught the lab very clearly. He is also a funny guy. Not boring at all in his lab.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm Exam: 20%
Final Exam: 30%
Homework: 20%
Project: 30%

Total 4 HW and 3 PA. Homework and Project are not too hard, so the mean is very high.

Midterm covered Ch.1-7. Open-book, this semester mean is ~77.

Final Exam covered only the topics after midterm, open-book. This semester mean is ~70.
reviews.comment_workload:
2 Lectures a week. (80mins/Lecture)
9 Labs/Tutorials (80mins/Lab) in total. No need to take attendence, online mode with video recording.

4 Credit course. A lot of content to study, required many hours to read the lecture notes. But lecture is not very necessary, I just attended in the first 2 weeks. Reading the lecutre notes is for doing HW, if you have anything not clear, you may need to watch the video of Lab.

Labs are not very important, but those labs for doing PA is useful, suggest not to skip.

reviews.author: VincentLi
reviews.comment_content: The content is not complicated and is easy to follow. However, the project assignment requires coding ability in c language. If you do not have previous knowledge of c, you will be very tough.

The lectures and tutorials are fine, and students can watch the recordings.
But almost no coding tutorial on how to work out project assignments. And the TA didn't give suggested solutions on how to work on project assignments.
reviews.comment_grading: I don't know yet.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is huge...
Students need to work out 4 homework, 3 project assignments, 1 midterm, and 1 final exam.

reviews.author: just another
reviews.comment_content: cover most of important topics in OS, including process, memeroy, disk managment, cpus
reviews.comment_teaching: teaching is OK, the slides and tutorial is fine. but you need read carefully for all the topics.
reviews.comment_grading:
very bad grading, too many people got C level.
including homework, mid term, projects and finals.
the project is the most easy part in this course.
the homework is not that easy but the exam is something like the problem in homework.
reviews.comment_workload: 4 homeworks with 3 projects, workload is fine but too many content. very like middle school homework.

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Memorization Game
reviews.comment_content:
1. OS structures
2. Process
3. Threads and Concurrency
4. CPU Scheduling
5. Synchronization
6. Deadlock
7. Memory management Strategies
8. Virtual Memory Management
9. Mass Storage Systems
10. File-System Interface and Implementation
11. Security and Protection

Basic introduction to Operating System concepts, individually speaking, they are pretty easy to understand, however, there's a huge amount of topics covered over the semester, making this pretty difficult to get through.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Li is pretty decent although he mostly repeats what's on the lecture slides, he does go through some examples which helps a lot. He also encourages students to ask question and sends us emails to elaborate on certain topics. Online semester also means you can just watch the lectures at 2x speed later. Feel free to attend or not.

Some topics are covered a bit messily, such as deadlock and banker's algorithm, mostly due to a lack of visualization. However for these you can simply go on youtube and learn them yourself.

For the labs, I skipped all of them since it's just the TA going over the notes again, however you should look at the tutorial slides as some of the example questions come up again in the homework and exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 assignments (20%, 5% each): some MCQs where you can copy the answers off the lecture slides, and then calculation questions.
Averages are high for all other than the 3rd homework where most people struggled with the synchronization problems (including me).

3 Programming assignments (30%, 10% each): Implement a simple version of concepts mentioned in class (pipes, scheduling and memory allocation for this semester), all 10 test cases are given, and to be honest they are quite easy.
Averages are very high, with a majority of students getting full marks.

Midterm (20%): Open book, open notes, 20 MCQs, and then calculation questions. The MCQs just require you to search through the slides (you are allowed to search within the PDF). For the calculation problems going over the past papers and the homework questions helps a LOT, you would know what and how they are going to ask since there's not much to ask. MUST NEED TO BE CAREFUL! Simple addition mistakes can lose you a lot of easy marks.
Averages are pretty high (67/100)

Final (35%): Same as midterm, 20 MCQs, and then calculation problems, only covers the latter half of the semester. Again going over the past paper and homework means you would know what is going to be asked. MUST NEED TO BE CAREFUL! Simple addition mistakes can lose you a lot of easy marks, particularly on the final since page replacement and disk scheduling questions are very easy to be careless on.
Averages are also high (69/100)

Overall it's more important for you to be careful rather than knowing the material well, so I don't think the assessment is very good, with 10~% over mean I got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Surprisingly low for COMP standards.

Assignments take an hour or two to finish, if you are stuck Google helps as people ask similar questions online.
Programming Assignments takes around half a day to finish, not much code has to be written. (200 lines at most maybe?)

While the exams are open note and open book, it is still important for you to study them such that you can find the related information during the exams. Doing the past papers and going over the homework questions again is a must since they are so similar to the exam.

reviews.author: agoti
reviews.title: "General Studies" for COMP students?
reviews.comment_content:
As described, the course teaches concepts and approaches to OS design, such as:
- Kernel structures
- Multiprogramming / concurrent execution of programs
- Multithreading and concurrent data access problems
- Data synchronization and deadlocks
- Memory allocation and virtual memory
- Secondary storage mechanisms  
- File system designs
- Resource access control

Some parts of this course feels like an extension of some Secondary School ICT topics that were quickly skimmed through (e.g. Purpose of OS, HDD mechanisms), but most of these are probably some supposedly "common sense" for COMP-related students.

A bit more focus are put on these (because they are easier to test? lol):
- Process Scheduling Policies
- Memory Swapping Policies
- (HDD) Disk Reading Policies
- Fork and Pipes
- Data synchronization
- Deadlock detection algorithm / Banker's algorithm
reviews.comment_teaching:
Charles tries his best to make this course as appealing as possible. Like mentioned by the other review, he made an anonymous "complain board" (sic) for ways to improve the teaching, and he also tried to make students (at least f2f ones) actively revise by setting up bonus questions (which started as giving bonus course points but was scrapped due to complaints of unfairness for non-f2f students).

I don't know how this course previously went, but judging by the slides (which Charles couldn't really do anything with) there's probably some improvement (e.g. skimming through the more "trivia" parts like how actual OSes implement some of the concepts). It is still a bit hard to revise properly because of that though.

Labs? What are those?
reviews.comment_grading:
...I'm not sure.

The previous reviews all mention about this course being memorization only, so I guess it has been changed (mostly by allowing open-notes). It now depends on how careful you are with MCs, calculations and filling tables.

Feels like it is very easy to lose points in both written assignments and exams due to carelessness (esp MCs), and those carelessness will very easily accumulate to a lower grade or something.

I lost a lot of points in finals due to carelessness (and sleeplessness due to spending all time on other courses and only the night before the exam studying this course) and that alone probably net me a drop by one grade.

As for range? I don't know. Didn't even remember my own score. Check out the other review on Charles, but I'm guessing A+ is like >95 based only my estimation of my own score.

Based on that data though, probably the curve is really squeezed in the high 80-100, confirming my "a little bit of carelessness spoils your grade" theory.
reviews.comment_workload:
It's not much.

4 written assignments,
2 "projects assignments" which are implementations of things taught in class (much easier than, say, COMP2012).

I don't know what's the correct amount of workload to be put into exams, but I guess being clear about the concepts (coffee questions are a good reference) + getting used to the "easier to test?"-type questions mentioned in the Content part is good enough. The exam is open-note so there is not much to memorize.

2. 2 projects.One is 10% and the other is 15%.
3.Mid term exam - 20%
4. Final exam - 35%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not very high. The assignments and projects have plenty of time to be finished.

reviews.author: Henry Wu
reviews.comment_content:
Principles, purpose and structure of operating systems; processes, threads, and multi-threaded programming; CPU scheduling; synchronization, mutual exclusion; memory management and virtual memory; device management; file systems, security and protection

many concepts, it is hard for me to understand them. don't know do what.
reviews.comment_teaching: didn't do to the lectures because it is very boring
reviews.comment_grading:
assignments: 20%
midterm:20%
final:35%
projects:25%

Finish all the assignments and projects then you will have a fair grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 assignments
2 projects
1 midterm + 1 final

just google the questions if you don't know how to do the assignments and projects.

reviews.author: harrier
reviews.title: don't expect OS course in UST :/
reviews.comment_content:
Content is basically same through out 20+ yrs, same with general OS course, concurrency, parallelism, file system, memory, task scheduling etc...

Personally I have background knowledge so I can accept it pretty fast (as I have experience in software exploitation), but could be hard to beginners (?) because of teaching.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecturer taught this course for over 20 years.
(but no one do related research in UST so good quality teaching is not expected :/)

Go to a few lectures in the beginning, feels boring :/ and mostly just follow the slides

Seems no one listen to lecturer in class....

I revise and learn new (?) concept by the slides, homework and pastpaper only.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 20% (@5%)
Project: 25% (10% & 15%)
Midterm: 20%
Final: 35%

^Copied from other review

Homework purely from question database, can "check" solution beforehand.
Project is simple and trivial, most people get full
Midterm and final can purely revise by reciting slides and past paper, and understand all concept that will be examined.

All marks are public released.

midterm = 9x/100
final = 97/100
overall = 96.x/100
Got overall third in the class and get A+, but have heard the A range is extremely narrow (rank 4x =~89% overall= B+) , so be careful :/
reviews.comment_workload: Homework and Project only, need time to do but simple enough.

reviews.author: Thomas_Wong
reviews.comment_content:
This course introduces the use and composition of the operating system. From Operating System Structures, to topics on Processes and Threads and also Memory and Storage Management.

The course contents may require both understanding of the concepts and also memorizing of the related contents, which students who are not good at memorizing  may need more time and effort.

The course covers topics which provides a deeper understand to computers, which could benefit software developers to improvise when developing software. Without this understanding of the operating system, code and program can still be written but this course surely would improve the scope of consideration during planning and developing of software.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The powerpoint summarize the contents but is not easy to understand the concepts simply by reading the slides. (It is possible but takes time) The textbook of the course has some more additional explanations and examples. It would be useful if certain concepts cannot be understand by just reading the powerpoint silides.

Prof LI has been teaching this course for a while, he is familiar with the content and concepts of the course. He explains the concepts in a detail and understandable way, not just by reading out the slides. (i.e. he tells the concepts by his own words and understanding) Therefore, I think his lecture would help a lot understanding the contents, if compared to reading from the powerpoint slides only.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme of the course is:

20% -- 4 written assignments (5% each)
25% -- 2 programming assignments (10% + 15%)
20% -- Midterm Exam
35% -- Final Exam

- no attendance is taken
- all assignments are individual assignments
- exams are closed-book
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload of the course is quite heavy. (refer to the "grading" section)

Written assignments are roughly 10MC questions and few pages of short questions. The assignments are not very difficult but takes time to complete.

Programming assignments are C++ programs involving the use of Nachos.

Revision or/and pre-study outside class would help really understanding the concepts, which may also make the workload of the course.

reviews.author: gossipgirl
reviews.comment_content:
Theoretical course content. Topics include:
Basics of OS, Types of OS, Process Concepts, Threads ,Process Scheduling and Synchronisation, Deadlock, Memory Management, Virtual Memory, File Systems, Mass Storage Systems.

Content isnt very difficult. Some easy calculations to do. Questions are fairly theoretical.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Well, if you like Desmond, he should be the best of instructors for the course. If not, you might find it hard to concentrate in classes.
But given the syllabus, I think he does a fine job explaining and giving practice/sample/possible questions in class. So going to class might help a tad bit.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading seems fine, not too lenient but too strict either.

4 Assignments 20%
2 Programming Assignments 25%
1 Midterm 20%
1 Final 35%

Mean of the midterm stays pretty high ~80.
Mean of the final stays fairly high ~70.
Exams aren't very difficult so high scores are possible.

Overall grade is similar to COMP2611.
~88% B+            ~90%  A-
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very light to be honest. The 2 programming assignments are nothing compared to those of 2011 and 2012.
Both assignments are barely 20-30 lines of C code.
The written assignments are slightly more challenging and they do require you to spend some time answering questions.

reviews.author: TryTryTry
reviews.comment_content: This course provides adequate but relatively easy content. Most topics require significant effort to memorize, while only a select few require calculation. Upon completion of the course, you will have a rough understanding of the basic structure and functionality of operating systems.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching could be improved as the professor tends to simply read off the slides, making it somewhat monotonous. Additionally, not enough examples are discussed during class. However, some examples are provided during the tutorials, which can be beneficial for deeper comprehension. Therefore, attending the tutorial sessions or watching the recorded videos would be helpful in gaining a better understanding of the course material.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is nice. 20% homework, 30% project, 20% midterm, 30 final. The average scores of midterm and final are 60 ~ 75. I obtained an A+ grade with a 95% overall score without putting in a significant amount of effort.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is reasonable. Each assignment can be completed promptly, while the three required projects involve the use of C Language. The first project may require a considerable amount of debugging effort, but the others are more manageable. Additionally, in preparation for the exam, completing around four past exam papers should suffice to earn a good grade.

reviews.author: henrychh927
reviews.comment_content:
There are mainly 2 parts of content. The first half is about processes and threads, and the second half is about memory and storage.

I found the first half to be practically useful, since multiprocessing and multithreading are very important when writing performant codes, particularly for AIs and games. It will come in handy when you study machine learning courses later, particularly for hyper-parameter tuning.

The second half talks about how the OS internally organize memory and storage. It may be useful to learn the terminologies, but the algorithms taught in this part don't really have much practical use, at least for me.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Zhang is a good communicator. During the lectures, she know how to give good examples when explaining the topics. And most importantly, she knows how to simplify the concept in layman terms for easier digestion. Compared to other professors in other courses, I think she is definitely above average in most aspects.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm Exam: 20%
Final Exam: 30%
4 Homeworks: 20%
3 Projects: 30%

For homeworks and projects, almost everyone is close to full marks. For "projects", they mean coding assignments. Since they already provided all the test cases for you and they use the same for grading, you can just check your program outputs to the expected outputs, then get all 100 marks.

Midterm covers processes/threads except deadlock, while final covers the rest. Not difficult, but easy to make mistakes, since there are lots of calculations. Most students get around 65-75 marks in these exams.
reviews.comment_workload: They don't expect you to have an easy time when it comes to workload. 4 homeworks and 3 coding assignments is probably on the level of a 4-credit course.

reviews.author: LinkedList
reviews.title: sBetter course than COMP2611 BUT still have many of improvement
reviews.comment_content:
Concept are varies from CPU , memory management etc,the struffes are mainly memorize and calculation should paid more attention because it 's easily to have mistake when you repeat to calculated the formula.(At least I usually make that type of mistakes.)

And I don 't think that it 's practical and only focus on theory.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kai is a good teacher that he paid many of efforts for student improvements(such as meeting with those students after mid term examination).

And sometimes would have in class discussion with students but sometimes he taught concept fast.
reviews.comment_grading:
In Chen Kai Class,my examination mark reach about average(Don 't know average whether equal to mean ) and my final grade is  B-.(Other lecture may be different,don 't know exact data)

But the difference between each sub grade is not far because assignment and Homework had already count about 45 marks.(They assume all students get full marks but I don t' have source so that HW only got 8x % each times and lose many marks there.)

So examination is the crux of grading.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is light and compared with COMP2611 it 's much easier but concept are too theory and it 's much better to make concepts applicable.

reviews.author: minus69
reviews.title: Easy course, fair grading, standard content, bad teaching
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Introduction
Chapter 2: Operating System Structures
Chapter 3: Processes
Chapter 4: Threads and Concurrency
Chapter 5: CPU Scheduling
Chapter 6: Synchronization tools
Chapter 7: Synchronization examples
Chapter 8: Deadlocks
Chapter 9: Memory Management Strategies
Chapter 10: Virtual-Memory Management
Chapter 11: Mass Storage Systems
Chapter 13: File-System Interface
Chapter 14: File-System Implementation
Chapter 17: Protection

Standard OS course content, you can find the exact same ppt slides from other universities' OS courses. Teaches basic algorithms in most topics which require no advanced math knowledge. Just +-x/.  Some OS concepts are relevant throughout the entire course, so it is good to have a clear early understanding of the course materials. Also you should be comfortable with binary and hexadecimal conversions.

Content before midterm (esp multithreading) is useful. Memory and storage are meh.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching was so-so. Prof basically just read aloud the lecture notes (with incomprehensible accent like other reviews mentioned). Only few students attended lectures.

If you want to have someone read the lecture notes for you, going to class is fine I guess. I did attend all the lectures just because I was too lazy to read the course material on my own. Prof was willing to answer questions in class/after class.

TA Peter was helpful. He explained the topics in the labs way better than prof did in the lectures. I recommend attending the labs.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is fair.
4 HW
3 Project assignments

Homework questions are similar to what will appear in the exams. Like other reviews mentioned, you will need to send emails to TA for clarifications to secure full mark due to the lack of clear instructions in some questions.

Project assignments each takes around 2 hours to finish except the first one which was challenging. The others were easy.

Doing the assignments (on your own) will help you prepare for the exams. Also do spend time to review course materials on a regular basis and you should be fine. I only spent 1-2 days doing revision before exams. Doing past paper from the last 3-4 years is good enough.

reviews.author: yongrui
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting content, and relevant to real life applications since we all use computers in our daily lives
reviews.comment_teaching: Lecturers very enthusiastic, although sometimes the explanation can be a little confusing due to slightly ambiguous english phrasing
reviews.comment_grading:
Almost everything is quite simple to score in. Assignments are straightforward, some parts even copy-paste from lecture notes.

Project is quite straigtforward as test cases are given to you.
reviews.comment_workload: Theres assignments and small projects, so workload is not trivial. I personally skipped tutorials so I could lessen my workload and it worked out fine.

reviews.author: Think
reviews.title: Memorization, just like 2611
reviews.comment_content:
Typical OS content

Very high level concepts of OS, with occasional C code references and POSIX libraries

The course covers a lot of topics, but without much depth, so memorization of concepts and a few important equations / algorithms would get you good grades.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Well, the concepts are memorization anyway, so I don't think teaching matters that much. Just read the materials and memorize key points, and you are done for the exams.

Nonetheless, I think teaching was above average: listening to the lectures clarified some points. Also, the TAs and the professor are super fast to reply emails and answer questions with good amount of details, which was quite helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
For this semester, it was entirely online.

4 HW 20%
2 PA (Programming Assigment) 30%
1 MT 20%
1 Final 30%

HW: conceptual questions. Some question answers can be found online.

PA: C programming assignment that covers one of the topic taught in class. You have to run it in the CSE lab machine, so get used to SSH and linux shell command. After that, the assignment themselves are not too hard.

Exams: Same format as HW. Almost the same questions, but with a little bit more difficulty.

HW and PA mean: ~90/100
MT mean: ~83/100 sd: 15 ish
Final mean: ~70/100 sd: 16 ish

I think the competition for the top grade is not too harsh for this course. If you can get around +1sd~1.5sd for the most part, you will get A+, whereas in other courses you might end up with an A with that score range.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is OK I think. There are many HWs throughout, but they are not too hard. It took me about 2~3 hrs per HW, and about 2~3 hours or less for the PA (once you know the concept, they are very easy).

reviews.author: sleepingbag
reviews.title: Good Course
reviews.comment_content: The course contains important concepts about how a computer actually works. To be more detailed, it talks about what sort of algorithm, methods, and designs that are implemented in a computer so that the usage computer resources could be maximized and users could have good experience when using the computer.
reviews.comment_teaching: Wang Wei is really enthusiastic and professional in teaching this course. He explained each line in the slide in detail, and added extra information in his speech to make things clearer.
reviews.comment_grading:
homework and programming assignment:
I believe most people get almost full mark, not a big deal in this course

midterm:
I suggest other students to be familiar with using those algorithm and techniques to get the answer. The questions are similar to the past paper. The more well-prepared you are, the better grade you would get.

final:
Final is harder than midterm. Though the concepts are separated into different chapters, it is really important to understand the concepts thoroughly and join all the knowledge pieces together.

I got pretty good scores in midterm and final so I couldn't really comment on the grade. I think the exams are not about how genius you are or how well you could program, but about how thoroughly you could understand the course materials. So if you pay more effort to understand the contents, you'll get A range with no doubt.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 programming assignment (easy, could finish in 2 hours, test cases were given in advance)
4 homework (easy MC questions, short answer questions)
midterm + final

reviews.author: jwnhy
reviews.title: Boring OS concepts
reviews.comment_content:
Common concepts about operating systems.
Most of them are like ancient and not updated with current OSs design.
All things need to know is right on the slides, so review the slides is sufficient for HW/Exams
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teacher is just a emotionless machine reading out what's on the slides.
So I didn't pay much attention to the lectures...
reviews.comment_grading:
It's open book and open notes.
Everybody gets a high mark in terms of 100, so many of them are getting a trash letter grades.
Most problems can be solved using slides.

My grade:
HW: 99/100 mean 90-ish
PA: 100/100 mean 90-ish
Mid: 89/100 mean 73 SD 10-ish
Final: 84/100 mean 70 SD 13

Overall: 92/100 mean 81-82?
Letter Grade: A

SHIT of SHIT
I don't think it's necessary for CSE students to work so hard just to learn outdated concepts and basic algorithms.

Highly competitive and TAs for most of the time make trivial and mistakes and you'll receive  a LOT clarafication in one semester.
In FINAL alone there are TWO round of grading due to marking scheme mistakes.

TAs and Prof. really don't give a shit to this course, but you have to if you want a decent grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Including 3 written assignment and 3 programming assignments.
Written assignment is just repeating concepts and few computation.
Programming assignments are more about "How to use OSs" instead of "How to design OSs and implement."

reviews.author: Ronleft
reviews.comment_content: This is an introductory course on operating systems. The topics will include the basic concepts of operating systems, process and threads, inter-process communications, process synchronization, scheduling, memory allocation, page and segmentation, secondary storage, I/O systems, file systems, security and protection. It contains the key concepts as well as examples drawn from a variety of real systems such as Microsoft Windows and Linux.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is detailed. You can gain a lot if you are patient.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 homework 20%
2 projects 30%
midterm 20%
final 30%
reviews.comment_workload: 4 assignments, 8 labs and 2 projects. Lab is not mandatory.

reviews.author: qjk
reviews.title: Epic grading and low workload, just like 2611. A+ gg ez Âú∞ÁçÑ‰∏âÈ†≠Áä¨ can be renamed kawaii ‰∏âÈ†≠Áä¨.
reviews.comment_content:
Processes, threads
CPU scheduling
Synchronization
Memory
Deadlock prevention and detection
Storage (Hard disk)

These were the most important topics off the top of my head.

Just like 2611, this course is memorization heavy, with a bit of maths and programming. I would say it's 60% memorization and 40% maths/programming. (which is just the right balance if you ask me.)

The content is extremely easy. It's hard not to get full marks when all the answers can be found on the lecture notes, and you can bring cheat sheets to the exam.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Li Bo and TA Peter are both great. They take their jobs seriously.

Peter built a website just to display our assignment grades. This dude is next level.

In both lectures and tutorials, the material is explained very clearly.

But the material is just too easy, there's no need to attend any lectures. Just read the lectures notes and tutorial notes yourself and watch the video if you come across a confusing topic.
reviews.comment_grading:
Overall ~97% -> A+ (^–∑^)-‚òÜ
This course is actually so easy, I am ashamed for not getting full marks. Everything nearly full, except the final exam in which I got ~90%.

Just like 2611, it is easy to get nearly full marks on everything in this course.

Midterm Exam 20%
Final Exam        30%
Homework        20%
Project                30%

Barring careless mistakes, getting full marks in the homeworks and the midterm should have been be easy. Everything could be found from the lecture notes.

The projects were even easier. "Projects" are actually just programming assignments. All the test cases are provided. You can't not get full marks even if you tried.

The final contained some tricky questions, so it was difficult to get full marks. Although I would say 90% of the answers can be found from the lecture notes (which you can print out and bring into the exam).
reviews.comment_workload:
Practically none.
HW x4 and Project x2 @ 3-4 hours each
Revision for exams will take 2 or 3 days if you want to cover all the materials.
